title: Violent bully threatened to ‘kick the baby out’ of pregnant girlfriend
text:
Gemma Cartledge, 33, says she endured years of physical and mental abuse at the hands of her ex Michael McGrath. (Picture: MEN Media)

A violent boyfriend threatened to ‘kick the baby out’ of his pregnant partner.

Gemma Cartledge, 33, says she endured years of physical and mental abuse at the hands of her ex Michael McGrath.

Too scared to get the police involved, she says she believed things would get better after having their little girl Lily-Grace.

But she says the violence came to a culmination in October 2016, when McGrath punched her in the face and made her nose ‘explode’.

He then threw a lasagna at her face and told her to ‘f***ing clean it up’, she says.

The mum-of-one decided to speak out after the thug was jailed for 10 months for violently abusing his current partner and two of her children.

She says her ex-partner’s ‘angry behaviour’ was evident from the very beginning. (Picture: MEN)

Gemma, a sales assistant from Hazelhust in Ashton-under-Lyne, said: ‘This story made me realise that it was not just a one-off.

Advertisement

‘I just feel like it needs to get out a bit more so people are aware of what he is.’

Gemma met McGrath through work in early 2014 and fell pregnant 18 months into the relationship.

She says her ex-partner’s ‘angry behaviour’ was evident from the very beginning.

‘He always wanted children and I thought that if I gave him something he wanted it would change. But it never did.’

Gemma said: ‘When I was pregnant he used to beat me up. He would ring my parents’ house if I would not answer the phone to him.

‘He would say he was going to kick the baby of out me.’

Gemma says things got worse when Lily-Grace was born.

On October 3, 2016, when the baby was six-months old, the couple had been out to get something for their daughter’s bedroom.

But McGrath got frustrated when he couldn’t put the item together.

Michael McGrath has been jailed (Picture: MEN Media)

‘He was getting angry and said ‘you go do it yourself’ and it got into a massive row.

‘He punched me in the face. It basically exploded everywhere. My little girl was screaming in the living room.

‘I had gone upstairs to clean my face and then he took a lasagna which was on the kitchen side ready to be cooked and he chucked that in my face.

‘He said ‘you need to f****g clean it up’, as if it was my fault.’

Gemma said she had to clean everything up because she was ‘so scared’ and only told the police when her parents warned that if she didn’t, they would

inform authorities themselves.

Advertisement

Advertisement

McGrath was arrested and charged and he pleaded guilty to two counts of common assault and one of harassment without violence at Tameside

Magistrates Court on October 3, 2016.

He was sentenced to a 12-month community order, made up of 12 rehabilitation days and 60 hours unpaid work, and was handed a 12-month

restraining order preventing him from contacting Gemma.

Three years later and McGrath, of Oldham, has been put behind bars for attacking the mother of his second child and her children.

On August 27 this year, he returned home from the pub after drinking nine pints of lager and punched Nicola Kennedy in the face.

He bit her 14-year-old son on the neck and slapped her 16-year-old daughter during a row about who was going to look after his 12-week-old baby.

As he held the baby in his arms McGrath shouted ‘you fat slag’ at the teenage girl and mocked her father, before mauling her brother as the lad tried to intervene.

Judge John Edwards told McGrath he was a ‘bully’ and sentenced him to 10 months in prison at Minshull Street Crown Court.

Gemma said she ‘does not think the sentence is long enough for what he did’.

‘He should not be laying fingers on children’, she added.

McGrath hasn’t had any contact with his daughter Lily-Grace since she was little.

Advertisement

Gemma has a new partner who her daughter ‘adores’ but is still worried about McGrath getting back in contact with them.

‘I’ve been in contact with people from Clare’s law to find out about how to check your partner’s past.

‘I don’t want him to be able to come into our lives.’
